text:
The Doggerbank is a large sandbank in the North Sea. It lies about from the coast of England. It is about long and wide. On average, the North Sea is deep. The average depth in the area of the Doggerbank is, at the shallowest place the water is only deep. During the last ice age, it was sometimes an island and sometimes a land bridge connecting Britain and Europe.
Today, the Doggerbank is important for fishing, in particular for cod and European plaice.
